Fund.ManagerBio: Chitnis is a managing director of YieldQuest Advisors and managing director of YieldQuest Securities. He has served as managing director of the YieldQuest Investment Group of Register & Akers Investments, from June 2004 to 2005 and, prior to that, of McDonald Investments, from September 2001 to June 2004. Chitnis led a similar team as managing director within Wachovia Securities from 1998 to 2001. Chitnis holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation and, secondarily, income. The fund generally invests at least 80% of assets in common stocks of companies of all market capitalizations, either directly or through investments in ETFs, actively managed closed end mutual funds, or REITs. It may invest up to one-third of assets in foreign stocks, including emerging market stocks. The fund may invest up to 20% of assets in securities that provide income and other fixed income securities. It may invest up to 5% of net assets in non-investment grade fixed income securities, commonly known as junk bonds.
Fund.Name: YieldQuest Core Equity

Holding.Company: Cook Cnty Ill Cmnty Cons Sch Dist 6%

Fund.ManagerBio: Chitnis is a managing director of YieldQuest Advisors and managing director of YieldQuest Securities. He has served as managing director of the YieldQuest Investment Group of Register & Akers Investments, from June 2004 to 2005 and, prior to that, of McDonald Investments, from September 2001 to June 2004. Chitnis led a similar team as managing director within Wachovia Securities from 1998 to 2001. Chitnis holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to maximize current tax-exempt income. The fund generally invests at least 80% of assets in municipal bonds exempt from both regular federal income tax and federal AMT, either directly or indirectly through ETFs and closed-end funds whose underlying investments in municipal bonds also are exempt from both federal income tax and federal AMT. It may invest up to 20% of net assets in other securities, including preferred stocks and taxable bonds, equity and/or mortgage REITs, and open-end mutual funds that employ hedging strategies.
Fund.Name: YieldQuest Tax Exempt Bond

Holding.Company: Western Asset-Claymore US Tr Inf Prt

Fund.ManagerBio: Chitnis is a managing director of YieldQuest Advisors and managing director of YieldQuest Securities. He has served as managing director of the YieldQuest Investment Group of Register & Akers Investments, from June 2004 to 2005 and, prior to that, of McDonald Investments, from September 2001 to June 2004. Chitnis led a similar team as managing director within Wachovia Securities from 1998 to 2001. Chitnis holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return. The fund invests in bonds, notes, mortgage-backed securities, corporate debt, mortgage REITs, preferred securities that make regular interest or dividend payments, government securities and short-term obligations, such as commercial paper and repurchase agreements. It may invest up to 25% of net assets in non-investment grade fixed income securities, commonly known as junk bonds. The fund invest no more than 5% of total assets in derivatives.
Fund.Name: YieldQuest Total Return Bond

Fund.ManagerBio: Yacktman is president of Yacktman Asset Management, a company he formed in March 1992. From 1983 to 1992, he managed Selected American Shares, for which he was named Morningstars 1991 Portfolio Manager of the Year. Prior to that, he was a portfolio manager at Stein Roe & Farnham from 1968 to 1982 and a partner at that firm from 1974 to 1982. He also has spent time at Continental Bank. Yacktman is a member of the Financial Analysts Society of Chicago.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital; current income is secondary. The fund invests primarily in equities, including convertibles. It may also invest in short-term money markets for income and long-term, high-quality debt for growth. There is no limitation on the percentage of assets that it may invest in any particular type of security. The advisor focuses on companies with large market capitalizations that have records of earnings growth and dividends.
Fund.Name: Yacktman

Fund.ManagerBio: Yacktman is president of Yacktman Asset Management, a company he formed in March 1992. From 1983 to 1992, he managed Selected American Shares, for which he was named Morningstars 1991 Portfolio Manager of the Year. Prior to that, he was a portfolio manager at Stein Roe & Farnham from 1968 to 1982 and a partner at that firm from 1974 to 1982. He also has spent time at Continental Bank. Yacktman is a member of the Financial Analysts Society of Chicago.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital; current income is secondary. The fund invests primarily in companies with market capitalizations of $1 billion or more, with long records of earnings growth and dividends. The advisor may focus on a relatively limited number of securities, generally 25 or less, other than money-market instruments. The fund may also purchase American depositary receipts. It is nondiversified.
Fund.Name: Yacktman Focused

Fund.ManagerBio: Fields is a vice president and investment officer with Wright Investors Service, his employer since 1982. Fields holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation. He is also a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks a high level of current income consistent with moderate fluctuations of principal. The fund invests at least 80% of total assets primarily in debt obligations issued or guaranteed by the U.S. government or any of agencies or instrumentalities, mortgage-related securities of governmental or corporate issuers and corporate debt securities.
Fund.Name: Wright Current Income Stnd

Fund.ManagerBio: Khandwala is an executive vice president as well as head of international and domestic equities with Wright Investors Service, his employer since 1986. Khandwala has been published in the journal of Portfolio Management and has been involved in conducting empirical research in finance. Khandwala is a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return consisting of price appreciation plus income. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in a diversified portfolio of equity securities of well-established non-U.S. companies. It typically maintains investments in at least three foreign countries. The fund seeks to outperform the MSCI Developed World ex U.S. index.
Fund.Name: Wright Intl Blue Chip Equities Stnd

Fund.ManagerBio: Kirtman is an executive vice president with Wright Investors Service, his employer since 2002. Prior to joining, he was a portfolio manager with William Blair & Company. Previously, he served as president and chief investment officer with Nikko Global Asset Management from April 1987 to June 1999. From January 1975 to April 1987, he was director of pension and profit sharing at Thomas J. Lipton, senior investment officer with Gerard Bank and assistant vice president at Provident National Bank.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return consisting of price appreciation plus income. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in a diversified portfolio of equity securities of well-established large capitalization companies. It may include common stocks, preferred stocks, and convertible securities. The fund seeks to outperform the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
Fund.Name: Wright Major Blue Chip Equities

Fund.ManagerBio: Simko is a vice president of investment research with Wright Investors Service, his employer since 1985. Simko holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term total return consisting of price appreciation and current income. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in a diversified portfolio of equity securities of well-established companies. It may include common stocks, preferred stocks, and convertible securities. The fund seeks to outperform the Standard & Poor's 400 index.
Fund.Name: Wright Selected Blue Chip Equities

Fund.ManagerBio: van Daalen is an executive vice president with Wright Investors Service, his employer since 2002. Prior to joining, he was director of Credit Suisse Asset Management. Previously, van Daalen spent seven years with Citibank, where he was assistant vice president and portfolio manager with the firm. From 1983 to 1985, he was a retail-banking manager at The Connecticut Bank and Trust Company. Prior to that, he was an analyst with Goldstein Krall Market Research from 1982 to 1983.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return consisting of a high level of income plus price appreciation. The fund invests at least 80% of total assets in U.S. government and investment grade corporate debt securities. The investment selections differ depending on the trend in interest rates. It looks for securities that will produce the best total return. The fund allocates assets among different market sectors with different maturities.
Fund.Name: Wright Total Return Bond

Fund.ManagerBio: van Daalen is an executive vice president with Wright Investors Service, his employer since 2002. Prior to joining, he was director of Credit Suisse Asset Management. Previously, van Daalen spent seven years with Citibank, where he was assistant vice president and portfolio manager with the firm. From 1983 to 1985, he was a retail-banking manager at The Connecticut Bank and Trust Company. Prior to that, he was an analyst with Goldstein Krall Market Research from 1982 to 1983.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks a high level of income which is normally above that available from short-term money market instruments or funds. The fund invests at least 80% of total assets in U.S. government obligations and maintains an average weighted maturity of between one and three years. It seeks to provide a level of income that is higher and less variable than income available from money-market instruments.
Fund.Name: Wright U.S. Government Near Term

Fund.ManagerBio: Pei is a co-founder and president of FEMMX Financial. She is the portfolio manager at the firm. Priviously, Pei headed a management consulting practice working with U.S. banks, investment companies and government entities in Japan, Hong Kong and the United Kingdom. She has also held positions at Crocker National Bank, Edgar Dunn and Co. and Citibank. Over the past six years she has worked with many organizations to advocate the securitization of micro-credit loans.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide long-term capital appreciation. The fund normally invests at least 80% of net assets in equity securities. In selecting investments, the Advisor and Sub-Advisor attempt to identify companies believed to have certain social responsibility criteria that are proactive towards women's social and economic equality and which market sectors are likely to achieve attractive returns while controlling portfolio risk. The fund seeks to purchase individual securities within each industry sector that have sound competitive positions and strategies that meet criteria for social responsibility.
Fund.Name: Women's Equity

Fund.ManagerBio: Pei is a co-founder and president of FEMMX Financial. She is the portfolio manager at the firm. Priviously, Pei headed a management consulting practice working with U.S. banks, investment companies and government entities in Japan, Hong Kong and the United Kingdom. Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide long-term capital appreciation. The fund normally invests at least 80% of net assets in equity securities. In selecting investments, the Advisor and Sub-Advisor attempt to identify companies believed to have certain social responsibility criteria that are proactive towards women's social and economic equality and which market sectors are likely to achieve attractive returns while controlling portfolio risk. The fund seeks to purchase individual securities within each industry sector that have sound competitive positions and strategies that meet criteria for social responsibility.
Fund.Name: Women's Equity I

Fund.ManagerBio: Suty is a vice president and senior portfolio manager of WM Advisors. Prior to joining WM Advisors in September 2005, he managed personal and foundation portfolios from January 2005 until August 2005. From December 1991 until December 2004, Suty was a portfolio manager of large-cap value stocks at Washington Capital Management, Inc. He was a principal and director of the firm. Suty holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks a relatively high level of current income and long-term growth of income and capital. The fund invests 80% of assets in dividend-paying common stocks and preferred stocks. It may also invest in bonds, convertible securities, U.S. government securities, ADRs and EDRs, mortgage-backed securities, repurchase agreements, and REIT securities. The fund invests up to 20% of assets in below-investment-grade fixed-income securities, U.S. government securities, asset-backed securities. It may invest up to 25% of assets in U.S. dollar-denominated securities of foreign issuers.
Fund.Name: WM Equity Income A

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. The fund invests primarily in equity securities of issuers located in foreign countries. It may invest up to 30% of assets in the securities of companies in, or governments of, developing or emerging markets, no more than 5% of assets in any one emerging market country. For temporary defensive purposes, the fund may invest a major portion of assets in securities of U.S. issuers. It may invest up to 5% of assets in investment-grade corporate fixed-income securities having maturities longer than one year, including euro-currency instruments and securities.
Fund.Name: WM International Growth A

Fund.ManagerBio: Coleman joined WM advisors in 2001.Prior to that, he was vice president and senior manager of Business Development at InfoSpace, Inc. Go2Net from 2000 until 2001, and member and general partner of Brookhaven Capital Management LLC Clyde Hill Research from 1989 until 2000.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. The fund invests at least 80% of assets in common stocks of companies having market capitalizations in the range of companies included in the S & P 400. It may invest in money market instruments. The fund may invest up to 20% of assets in REIT securities. It may invest in fixed-income securities of any maturity, including mortgage-backed securities, and may invest up to 20% of assets in below-investment-grade fixed-income securities. The fund may invest up to 25% of assets in U.S. dollar-denominated securities of foreign issuers.
Fund.Name: WM Mid Cap Stock A

Fund.ManagerBio: Simpson joined WM Advisors as a senior investment analyst and portfolio manager in March 1993. He currently serves as vice president and senior portfolio manager Previously, he spent six years as a senior consultant with Management Advising Services and one year as a research executive with Stonemark. Simpson holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide a high level of current income and long-term capital appreciation. The fund invests 80% of assets in real estate investment trust ("REIT ) securities or debt securities of issuers that are principally engaged in the U.S. real estate or related industries. In selecting investments for the fund, WM Advisors looks for REITs at attractive values which have fundamental indicators of dividend growth potential, capital appreciation, a strong financial position, and solid management.
Fund.Name: WM REIT A

Fund.ManagerBio: Sosey is vice president and portfolio manager wtih WM Advisors, Inc., his employer since 1998. Previously, he was assistant treasurer of California Federal Bank, where he was employed for over eight years.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks current income consistent with stability of principal. The fund normally invests in U.S. government obligations, corporate debt, and/or mortgage-related securities rated AA or AAA. The dollar-weighted average maturity is usually three or fewer years.
Fund.Name: WM Short Term Income A

Fund.ManagerBio: Sosey is vice president and portfolio manager wtih WM Advisors, Inc., his employer since 1998. Previously, he was assistant treasurer of California Federal Bank, where he was employed for over eight years.

Fund.ManagerBio: Bassett is senior vice president, chief investment officer and senior portfolio manager with Delaware Investments. He joined Delaware Investment in 1997. Priviously, he served as a vice president with Morgan Stanley Asset Management, where he analyzed small growth companies. Prior to that, he worked as a trust officer at Sovran Bank and Trust Company.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation; income is incidental. The fund invests at least 80% of net assets in equity securities of companies with market capitalizations in the range represented by the Russell 2000(R) Index. It may also invest in money market instruments. The fund may invest up to 25% of assets in securities of foreign issuers provided that no more than 5% of total assets are to be invested in securities of issuers located in developing or emerging market countries. It may invest up to 20% of assets in below-investment-grade fixed-income securities.
Fund.Name: WM Small Cap Growth A

Fund.ManagerBio: Yoakum is a senior vice president and chief investment strategist of WM Advisors. Between 1997 and 1999, he was chief investment officer for D.A. Davidson & Co. (DADCO). Between 1994 and 1997, Yoakum was the senior vice president and managing director of portfolio management for Boatmens Trust Company.prior to that, he was senior vice president and chief equity officer for Composite Research & Management Co.for eight years. Yoakum holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide as high a level of total return consisting of reinvested income and capital appreciation. The portfolio invests assets among certain of the funds. It invests at least 30% and no more than 70% of net assets in the equity funds and at least 30% and no more than 70% in the fixed-income funds. The portfolio may invest up to 40% of assets in each of the short term income, U.S. government securities, income, high yield, and money market funds. It may also invest up to 30% of assets in each of the REIT, equity income, growth & income, west coast equity, mid cap stock, growth, small cap value, small cap growth, and international growth funds. The portfolio may also invest in U.S. government securities, fixed-income securities rated A or higher, commercial paper, bank obligations, repurchase agreements, and strategic transactions such as futures contracts and options.
Fund.Name: WM Str Asset Mgmt Balanced A

Between 1994 and 1997, Yoakum was the senior vice president and managing director of portfolio management for Boatmens Trust Company.prior to that, he was senior vice president and chief equity officer for Composite Research & Management Co.for eight years. Yoakum holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide long-term capital appreciation. The portfolio invests assets among certain of the funds. It generally invests at least 60% of net assets in the equity funds. The portfolio may invest up to 30% of assets in each of the short term income, U.S. government securities, income, high yield, and money market funds. It may also invest up to 40% of assets in each of the REIT, equity Income, growth & income, west coast equity, mid cap stock, growth, small cap value, small cap growth, and international growth funds. The portfolio may also invest in U.S. government securities, and fixed-income securities rated A or higher.

Fund.ManagerBio: Byron is a vice president and portfolio manager with Van Kampen American Capital, his employer since 1981.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide long-term capital appreciation. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in Municipal Obligations, including inverse floating rate obligations, under normal market conditions. It may invest 20% of assets in bonds below investment grade. The fund may also invest up to 50% of assets in taxable short-term investments such as: U.S. Government securities; obligations of U.S. banks and time or demand deposits in U.S. banks. It may invest up to 20% of assets in AMT-subject bonds.
Fund.Name: WM Tax-Exempt Bond A

Fund.ManagerBio: Sosey is vice president and portfolio manager wtih WM Advisors, Inc., his employer since 1998. Previously, he was assistant treasurer of California Federal Bank, where he was employed for over eight years.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks current income consistent with safety and liquidity. The fund invests primarily in a selection of obligations of the U.S. government and its agencies. It may also invest in collateralized mortgage obligations and repurchase agreements. The fund may invest up to 5% of total net assets for emergency, non-investment purposes. It may also enter into dollar roll transactions limited in aggregate to no more than 25% of net assets.
Fund.Name: WM U.S. Government Secs A

Fund.ManagerBio: Foreman is a vice president and senior portfolio manager of WM Advisors. He has been employed by WM Advisors since January of 2002. Prior to that, he was senior vice president at Evergreen Asset Management Co. from 1999 until 2002, and vice president and senior portfolio manager at WM Advisors from 1991 until 1999. Foreman holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in common stocks issued by companies headquartered in Alaska, California, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, and Washington. It may also invest in stocks issued by other companies that do business in the Northwest. The fund may invest up to 20% of assets in real estate investment trusts (REITs).
Fund.Name: WM West Coast Equity A

Fund.ManagerBio: Davenport is a portfolio manager with Atlanta Investment Counsel. He worked previousy as a stockbroker and has held advisory positions with various investment company service providers.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide investors with a maximum total return. The fund typically will invest at least 65% of assets in publicly traded securities held by Berkshire Hathaway Holdings (BHH). It is the intent of the fund to own each security in the same relative percentage as that security represents the total investment portfolio of BHH. This fund is non-diversified.
Fund.Name: Wisdom B

Fund.ManagerBio: Fobes is the chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Berkshire Capital Holdings. Prior to forming the firm in 1993, he was with Adobe Systems.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in the securities of companies engaged in the development, production, or distribution of wireless related products or services. Companies that are candidates for the fund include, but are not limited to communication services; communication equipment; software and programming; computer hardware; peripherals; storage devices; semiconductors; and data networking for the wireless industry. It may invest in both small and large companies, without regard to their size. The fund is nondiversified.
Fund.Name: Wireless

Fund.ManagerBio: Winters is the the managing member of Wintergreen Advisers. Prior to forming Wintergreen Advisers in May 2005, he held various positions with Franklin Mutual Advisers, LLC, including, president, chief executive officer and chief investment officer, and he was a research analyst for Heine Securities Corporation, the former investment manager for the Franklin Mutual Series Fund. Winters holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. The fund invests mainly in equity securities (including securities convertible into, or that the Investment Manager expects to be exchanged for, common or preferred stock) of companies of any nation that the investment manager believes are available at market prices less than their value. It expects to invest substantially and invests up to 100% of assets in foreign securities.
Fund.Name: Wintergreen

Fund.ManagerBio: Robinson is a founder and president of Winslow Management Company, he has over 30 years of money management experience. Since 1991. Robinson has focused exclusively on green investing. As the chief portfolio manager for Winslow Management Company, he currently manages environmentally sensitive assets in individual accounts, institutional accounts, and in the Green Century Balanced Fund, a publicly traded mutual fund.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation through environmentally responsible investing. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in equity securities of domestic small and medium size companies that adviser believes are enviromentally responsible, best in class companies, reasonable priced and exhibit the potential for superior growth.
Fund.Name: Winslow Green Growth

Fund.ManagerBio: Robinson is a founder and president of Winslow Management Company, he has over 30 years of money management experience. Since 1991. Robinson has focused exclusively on green investing. As the chief portfolio manager for Winslow Management Company, he currently manages environmentally sensitive assets in individual accounts, institutional accounts, and in the Green Century Balanced Fund, a publicly traded mutual fund.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation through environmentally responsible investing. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in equity securities of domestic small and medium size companies that adviser believes are enviromentally responsible, best in class companies, reasonable priced and exhibit the potential for superior growth.
Fund.Name: Winslow Green Growth Instl

Fund.ManagerBio: Jordan is a portfolio manager for HJMC which he has been with since 1996. Prior to this postion he spent three years as a position block trader for Salomon Brothers. Upon his graduation from Harvard Business School he found and managed Lighthouse Management, L.P., a small investment firm.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. The fund invests primarily in publicly trades stocks of U.S. companies irrespective of market capitalization size. It may invest up to 25% of total assets in the securities of foreign issuers. The fund will not invest more than 35% of total assets in debt securities, including direct and indirect obligations of the U.S. Government. It may also invest up to 25% of total assets in U.S debt securities that are not investment grade securities. The fund is nondiversified.
Fund.Name: Jordan Opportunity

Fund.ManagerBio: Stevens is a chairman and principal with L.A. Capital. He co-founded L.A. Capital in 2002. Prior to co-founding L.A. Capital, Stevens was senior managing director and principal at Wilshire Associates. He joined Wilshire in 1980 and for six years directed its Equity Division. In 1986, Stevens assumed responsibility for Wilshire Asset Management and for the next 16 years headed that division. Stevens holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to replicate as closely as possible the performance of the index before the deduction of Portfolio expenses. The fund invests primarily in the common stock of companies included in the index that are representative of the Index. It uses enhanced "stratified sampling" techniques in an attempt to replicate the return of the index. The fund holds stocks representing at least 90% of the total market value of the index.
Fund.Name: Dow Jones Wilshire 5000 Index Port Instl

Fund.ManagerBio: Stevens is a chairman and principal with L.A. Capital. He co-founded L.A. Capital in 2002. Prior to co-founding L.A. Capital, Stevens was senior managing director and principal at Wilshire Associates. He joined Wilshire in 1980 and for six years directed its Equity Division. In 1986, Stevens assumed responsibility for Wilshire Asset Management and for the next 16 years headed that division. Stevens holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.

In 1986, Stevens assumed responsibility for Wilshire Asset Management and for the next 16 years headed that division. Stevens holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide investment results of a portfolio of publicly traded common stocks of companies in the portion of the Wilshire 5000 index identified as large-cap, growth companies. The fund invests in the large company growth segment of the U.S. equity market. It invests substantially all the assets in companies with the largest market capitalizations greater than approximately $1.9 billion. The fund invests in companies that have above average earnings or sales growth histories and retention of earnings and have above average price to earnings ratios.
Fund.Name: Wilshire Large Company Growth Instl

Fund.ManagerBio: Stevens is a chairman and principal with L.A. Capital. He co-founded L.A. Capital in 2002. Prior to co-founding L.A. Capital, Stevens was senior managing director and principal at Wilshire Associates. He joined Wilshire in 1980 and for six years directed its Equity Division. In 1986, Stevens assumed responsibility for Wilshire Asset Management and for the next 16 years headed that division. Stevens holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.

Fund.ManagerBio: Healey is an executive vice president and has been a portfolio manager with T. Leavell & Associates Inc. since February 1986. Prior to joining the company, he spent 11 years as an analyst and portfolio manager with Torchmark Investment Advisory Company. As a fixed-income manager, Healey seeks a high-quality portfolio with low turnover and intermediate duration.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks income exempt from federal and Alabama personal income taxes, consistent with preservation of capital. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in municipal obligations. Investments consist chiefly of debt securities issued by Alabama, but may also include U.S. government obligations, commercial paper, bank obligations, and cash. The fund may invest in zero-coupon or deferred-interest bonds. It may also invest in bonds that are subject to the alternative minimum tax. The fund is nondiversified.
Fund.Name: Alabama Tax-Free Bond

Prior to joining Davenport & Company, he worked as a Portfolio Manager for Central Fidelity Bank. Ackerly is a member of the Investment Policy Committee and serves on the Board of Directors. Ackerly holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital;current income is incidental to this objective and may not be significant. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in common stocks. It may invest the balance of assets in preferred stocks, convertible preferred stocks, convertible bonds, and warrants. The fund may invest up to 20% of assets in the equity securities of foreign issuers. It does not limit the fund to any particular market capitalization requirements when selecting stocks.
Fund.Name: Davenport Equity

Fund.ManagerBio: Bruce is a principal with Flippin, Bruce & Porter, where he has been a partner since 1985. Previously, he spent six years as a portfolio manager for Capitoline Investment Service and two years as a stockbroker for Anderson & Strudwick. Bruce attempts to look beyond current investor emotion and to discount Wall Street expectations, seeking instead to relate historical financial-company characteristics to current price.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation and current income is a secondary objective. The fund invests in a balanced portfolio of equity and fixed-income securities assuming a moderate level of investment risk. The equity portion normally ranges between 40% and 70% of assets; the fixed-income portion ranges between 25% and 50% of assets; and the money market instruments portion ranges between 0% and 35% of assets.
Fund.Name: FBP Balanced

Fund.ManagerBio: Bruce is a principal with Flippin, Bruce & Porter, where he has been a partner since 1985. Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital and income is a secondary objective. The fund normally invests 80-100% of net assets in a diversified portfolio comprised primarily of equity securities, while money market instruments will comprise 0-20%. It may invest in a variety of companies, industries and economic sectors to seek the best opportunities for capital appreciation and growth with limited risk. The fund will primarily be invested in the securities of the largest 1000 companies having operating histories of 10 years or longer.
Fund.Name: FBP Value

Fund.ManagerBio: Hope is vice president of T. Leavell & Associates, Inc. and has been employed by the company since 1987.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks income consistent with capital preservation. The fund normally invests at least 40% of assets in U.S.government securities. It may invest in investment-grade corporate debt and money market instruments. The fund maintains an average weighted maturity of three to seven years. Its investments may include floating rate securities.
Fund.Name: Government Street Bond

Fund.ManagerBio: Leavell has been a principal of T. Leavell & Associates, Inc since his founding of the firm in 1979.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. The fund invests at least 80% of total assets in the common stocks of medium to large capitalization companies which are broadly diversified among economic sectors and industries. The net result of selection is a stock universe of approximately 350 stocks. Stocks in the universe are then characterized by their diversification characteristics. Stocks are grouped into either "growth" or "value" stocks. Each group is then sorted into capitalization sectors using the capitalization sector weightings of the S&P 500 as benchmarks.
Fund.Name: Government Street Equity

Fund.ManagerBio: Healey is an executive vice president and has been a portfolio manager with T. Leavell & Associates Inc. since February 1986. Prior to joining the company, he spent 11 years as an analyst and portfolio manager with Torchmark Investment Advisory Company. As a fixed-income manager, Healey seeks a high-quality portfolio with low turnover and intermediate duration.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. The fund invests at least 80% in common stocks of medium capitalization companies whose market capitalization falls within the range of the S&P MidCap 400 index and approximately $350 million to $14.8 billion. Stocks are grouped into either "growth or "value stocks. Each group is then sorted into ten economic sectors. The fund may write covered call options.
Fund.Name: Government Street Mid-Cap

Fund.ManagerBio: Caravati is a vice president and portfolio manager for Lowe, Brockenbrough & Company, Inc. Previously, he was an account manager at NationsBank. He has over nine years of investment experience. Caravati holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital and income. The fund invests in equity and investment grade debt securities, with varying percentages of each type ranging from a minimum of 25% to a maximum of 75%. To determine the relative holdings, the fund examines the relationship between projected returns of the S&P index and U.S. Treasury obligations. Equity investments are made primarily for growth, using strong fundamental factors, high stock rankings, and attractive technical factors.
Fund.Name: Jamestown Balanced

Fund.ManagerBio: Caravati is a vice president and portfolio manager for Lowe, Brockenbrough & Company, Inc. Previously, he was an account manager at NationsBank. He has over nine years of investment experience. Caravati holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital. The fund normally invests in a diversified portfolio composed primarily of common stocks, preferred stocks, convertible preferred stocks and convertible bonds. It seeks financially strong, relatively large companies which offer above average earnings and relatively modest valuations. The fund may invest in a variety of companies, industries and economic sectors. Under normal circumstances, at least 80% of net assets will be invested in equity securities.
Fund.Name: Jamestown Equity

Fund.ManagerBio: Roche is a senior portfolio manager and director with Victory Capital Management, his employer since 2002. Previously, he was a vice president at The MuniCenter and served as a municipal bond product manager for Merrill Lynch where he managed municipal bond portfolios.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return. The fund invests primarily in equity securities of non-U.S. companies. It invests at least 80% of net assets in equity securities of issuers located in 12 or more foreign countries. The fund invests primarily in developed countries but may invest in emerging market countries. As a defensive measure, the fund may hedge up to 50% of the value of investments in international markets by investing in forward currency exchange contracts in an effort to modify the effects of currency fluctuations.
Fund.Name: Jamestown International Equity

It typically invests at least 65% of assets in Virginia tax-exempt securities. The fund invests at least 75% of assets in securities rated A or better. The fund may also invest in debentures, notes, convertible debt securities, municipal securities, mortgage-related securities, and certain collateralized and asset-backed securities. He is chair and chief investment officer of Gabelli Funds, which he formed in 1977. He began his investment career in 1967 as an analyst with Loeb, Rhoades & Company. In 1975, he joined William D. Witter, a Wall Street research boutique. Gabelli holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. The fund primarily invests in common stocks of micro-cap companies with a market capitalization of $300 million or less at the time of purchase. It focuses on micro-cap companies which appear to be underpriced relative to their private market value. Private market value is the value the adviser believes informed investors would be willing to pay to acquire a company. Micro-cap companies may also be new or unseasoned companies that can also be engaged in new and emerging industries.
Fund.Name: Westwood Mighty Mites AAA

Fund.ManagerBio: Gabelli has served as chairman, chief executive officer, chief investment officer-value products and a director of GAMCO Investors, Inc. (GAMI) since November 1976. He is chair and chief investment officer of Gabelli Funds, which he formed in 1977. He began his investment career in 1967 as an analyst with Loeb, Rhoades & Company. In 1975, he joined William D. Witter, a Wall Street research boutique. Gabelli holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. The fund primarily invests in common stocks of micro-cap companies with a market capitalization of $300 million or less at the time of purchase. It focuses on micro-cap companies which appear to be underpriced relative to their private market value. Private market value is the value the adviser believes informed investors would be willing to pay to acquire a company. Micro-cap companies may also be new or unseasoned companies that can also be engaged in new and emerging industries.
Fund.Name: Westwood Mighty Mites C

Fund.ManagerBio: No Bio.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. The fund invests at least 80% of net assets in a portfolio of common stocks of smaller companies that have a market capitalization of between $100 million and $2.5 billion at the time of purchase. It may invest in relatively new or unseasoned companies, which are in their early stages of development, or small companies in new and emerging industries.

Byrne is a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts, the Committee of 200, and the International Womens Forum. She has more than 35 years of investment experience.

The fund will generally invest in securities of domestic companies, but may also invest in foreign securities and ADRs.

He is primarily responsible for managing portfolios of institutional fixed income clients. Previously, he spent two years at Fidelity Bank where he served as vice president of fixed income. Prior to that, he was employed at National Investment Services of America where he left as vice president and portfolio manager of fixed income. Stevens is a Chartered Financial Analyst.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks income exempt from federal and Colorado income taxes. Under normal circumstances, the fund will invest at least 80% of the value of net assets plus any borrowings for investment purposes in investments, the income from which is exempt from both federal and Colorado state income tax, including securities of issuers not located in Colorado if the income from such securities is so exempt. The fund may invest up to 25% of its total assets in Colorado municipal bonds rated at the time of purchase in the fourth highest investment-grade category. This fund is nondiversified.
Fund.Name: Westcore CO Tax-Exempt

Fund.ManagerBio: Lock is a vice president for Denver Investment Advisors, where he has been since 1989. He has been active in the management of fixed-income securities for 11 years.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks maximum long-term total return. The fund normally invests primarily in a wide variety of income-producing securities such as corporate bonds and notes, government securities and high-yielding equity securities. Under normal circumstances, the fund will invest at least 80% of the value of its net assets plus any borrowings for investment purposes in income-producing securities. The fund may invest up to 20% of its assets in common stocks, primarily dividend paying. The fund may own an unlimited amount of high-yield/high-risk bonds.

Fund.ManagerBio: Moscatelli is vice president of Denver Investment Advisors and director of Large-Cap Growth Equity Research. From 1995 to 1997, he worked as an investment banking financial analyst associate with Morgan Keegan & Company, Inc. Moscatelli holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.

The fund invests primarily in the common stock of companies with market capitalizations of $2 billion and above at the time of purchase with the ability to produce superior revenue and earnings growth. The adviser seeks to blend a portfolio of core growth holdings which are suited for multiple business cycles and tactical growth holdings which are suited for the current business cycle.

Schor holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term growth of capital. The fund invests primarily in the common stock of international companies with market capitalizations of $1.5 billion or less at the time of purchase that meet the Adviser's investment criteria. Under normal circumstances, the Fund invests at least 65% of its assets in common stocks of foreign companies in developed countries. In addition, the fund may invest in larger foreign companies or in U.S.-based companies if, in our opinion, they represent better prospects for long-term growth than smaller foreign companies or than foreign companies generally.
Fund.Name: Westcore International Frontier

Fund.ManagerBio: Adelmann holds the Chartered Financial Analyst and Certified Public Accountant designations.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. Under normal circumstances, the fund invests at least 80% of the value of net assets plus any borrowings for investment purposes in mid-cap companies whose stocks appear to be undervalued. The fund currently considers mid-cap companies to be companies with market capitalizations of $500 million to $12 billion at the time of purchase.
Fund.Name: Westcore Mid-Cap Value

Fund.ManagerBio: Chester is responsible for the day-to-day co-management of the Westcore Select and MIDCO Growth Funds. He has been conducting equity research for Denver Investment Advisors for 15 years. In 2000, he assumed responsibility as director of Denver Investment Advisors growth equity research efforts. Prior to joining Denver Investment Advisors LLC, Will gained economic experience at Centennial Precious Metals and the University of Denver. Chester holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. The fund invests primarily in medium-size companies, using valuation techniques that emphasize earnings growth. Under normal circumstances, the fund invests at least 80% of the value of its net assets plus any borrowings for investment purposes in mid-cap companies. For purposes of this policy, the fund currently considers mid-cap companies to be companies whose market capitalizations, at the time of purchase, are between $500 million and $12 billion.
Fund.Name: Westcore Midco Growth

Fund.ManagerBio: Mr. McKissick is a Vice President of Denver Investment Advisors. Mr. McKissick has been a fixed income research analyst with Denver Investment Advisors since 1999. Prior to joining Denver Investment Advisors, he was a Senior Research Analyst at Hotchkis & Wiley for two years.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks current income. The fund normally invests invests in investment-grade debt securities, those rated in the top four rating categories by at least one nationally recognized rating agency. Under normal circumstances, the fund will invest at least 80% of the value of net assets plus any borrowings for investment purposes in fixed income securities of varying maturities. The dollar-weighted average quality is expected to be Baa or better. The fund may invest up to 35% of assets in high-yield or high-risk securities, meaning equity and equity related securities and below investment-grade bonds.

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation and income. The fund invests in a diversified portfolio of equity and debt securities. Normally, the asset mix of the fund will range between its assets in common stocks and convertible securities, 30-70% in preferred stock and bonds, and 0-40% in money market instruments. The fund will include stocks that pay dividends and will attempt to maintain an above average dividend yield. It will also invest at least 25% of assets in fixed income senior securities.

The fund normally invests at least 65% of assets in investment-grade securities, although it is permitted to include any type of debt instrument. It invests in those sectors of the bond market that offer the highest yield in relation to historical yield spreads. It attempts to achieve above average returns by recognizing changing relative yields and allocating the assets of the fund into the most attractive market and maturity sectors. The fund may invest in bonds of any maturity.

Potential investments may include U.S. and foreign common stocks, American Depositary receipts (up to 25% of assets), convertible bonds, and other investment-grade corporate debt obligations.

The fund invests primarily in a diversified portfolio of common stocks of small-sized companies similar in size to those within the Russell 2000 Index. It normally invests in companies in market sectors that offer the highest growth potential, which historically have been telecommunication, computer hardware and software, technology, health care, and biotechnology. However, the fund may invest in other sectors if, in the Advisor's opinion, they offer a better opportunity for growth.

The fund's bond portion generally maintains an average maturity of 20 years or more. The money market portion is generally comprised of high-quality instruments. The fund's neutral target allocation is 60% equity securites and 40% fixed-income securities.

The fund invests primarily in large-capitalization securities, defined as securities of companies with market capitalizations of $1 billion or more. It also seeks total return by targeting companies believed to be undervalued, possesses strong financial positions and have a consistency and predictability in their earnings growth.

Fund.ManagerBio: No Bio.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks maximum long-term total return consistent with minimizing risk to principal. The fund primarily invests in mid-capitalization securities, defined as securities of companies with market capitalizations within the range of companies comprising the Russell Midcap Value Index. As of December 31, 2003, this range was $500 million to $16 billion and is expected to change frequently. The fund seeks total return by selecting companies believed to be undervalued and which possesses strong financial positions.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage C&B Mid Cap Val A

Fund.ManagerBio: Galiani joined Wells Capital Management in 1997 and is the firms managing director for municipals with overall managerial responsibility for municipal strategy, portfolio management, credit research and trade execution. Prior to joining the firm, he served as director of fixed-income from 1995 to 1997 for Qualivest Capital Management. He was president from 1990 to 1995 of Galiani Asset Management Corporation, an investment advisory practice.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks income exempt from federal and California income taxes while preserving capital. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in municipal securities that pay interest exempt from federal income tax and California individual income tax; up to 20% of assets in securities that pay interest subject to federal income taxes, including federal AMT; and up to 10% of total assets in below investment-grade municipal securities, including unrated securities which are classified as below investment-grade quality.The average expected duration of the funds portfolio may be from one to five years. The fund is nondiversified.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage CA Ltd-Term T/F A

Fund.ManagerBio: Pence is a portfolio manager at Wells Fargo. Previously, he was a portfolio manager with Strong Capital Management from October 2000 to April 2005. Pence holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.

Fund.ManagerBio: Evans joined Wells Capital Management in 2000 managing public fixed income and municipal bond mutual funds and institutional private accounts on the Tax-Exempt Fixed Income Team. Prior to joining the firm in 2000, Evans was responsible for the investment operations of PennCorp Financial Group, a $6 billion life and health insurance company, as its Chief Investment Officer from 1995 to 1999.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks high current income exempt from federal and Colorado income taxes, consistent with the preservation of capital. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in municipal securities that pay interest exempt from the above taxes; up to 25% of assets in securities of related issuers or in securities of any one issuer; up to 20% of assets in securities that pay interest subject to federal income taxes, including federal AMT; and up to 10% of assets in below investment-grade municipal securities, including unrated securities. The fund is nondiversified.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage CO Tax-Free A

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks growth of capital. The fund normally invests at least 80% of net assets in common stock of small- and medium-capitalization companies that the fund's management believes are underpriced but have attractive growth prospects. The fund managers base their analysis on the price and investor would be willing to pay for the entire company given its management, financial health, and growth potential.

Fund.ManagerBio: Rilling is a portfolio manager with Strong Capital Management.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return. The fund normally invests at least 80% of net assets in intermediate maturity bonds issued by U.S. companies. The fund invests 75% of net assets in investment grade debt obligations. To increase income payouts, it may also invest up to 25% of net assets in lower quality, high yield bonds with positive or improving credit fundamentals. The funds average effective maturity will normally be between seven and twelve years.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Corporate Bond Adv

Fund.ManagerBio: Pence is a portfolio manager at Wells Fargo. Previously, he was a portfolio manager with Strong Capital Management from October 2000 to April 2005. Previously, he was chief equity investment officer and portfolio manager at Conseco Capital Management and a senior security analyst at another company in the forest-products and natural-gas industries. Pence holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital growth. The fund invests in a diversified portfolio of common stocks from small-, medium-, and large-capitalization companies. When the managers believe market conditions favor fixed-income investments, the managers have the flexibility to invest up to 100% of the funds assets in in bonds. The fund would primarily invest in intermediate- and long-term grade bonds.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Discovery Adm

Fund.ManagerBio: Pence is a portfolio manager at Wells Fargo. Previously, he was a portfolio manager with Strong Capital Management from October 2000 to April 2005. Previously, he was chief equity investment officer and portfolio manager at Conseco Capital Management and a senior security analyst at another company in the forest-products and natural-gas industries. Pence holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital growth. The fund invests in a diversified portfolio of common stocks from small-, medium-, and large-capitalization companies. When the managers believe market conditions favor fixed-income investments, the managers have the flexibility to invest up to 100% of the funds assets in in bonds. The fund would primarily invest in intermediate- and long-term grade bonds.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Discovery Inv

Fund.ManagerBio: Chan has served as a member of Wells Fargo Funds Managements asset allocation team and investment team since 2002. He has more than 9 years of investment experience. Chan holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return. The fund normally invests at least 80% of the funds assets in debt securities, which include U.S. government obligations, mortgage- or asset-backed securities and dollar-denominated debt securities of U.S. branches of foreign banks.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Divers Bond Adm

Fund.ManagerBio: No Bio.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital growth while moderating annual return volatility. The fund normally invests at least 65% of assets in equities. It employs five equity investment styles to minimize volatility. The fund typically invests the following percentages in each of these investment styles: 25% in Large Company Growth, 10% in Small Company Growth, 15% in International, 25% in Income Equity, and 25% in Index, which attempts to replicate the performance of the S&P 500.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Diversified Eq A

Fund.ManagerBio: Coin is senior vice president and portfolio manager with Peregrine Capital Management, his employer since 1995. Prior to joining the firm, he was a research officer with Lord Asset Management. Coin is a Chartered Financial Analyst.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation with moderate annual return volatility. The fund is a gateway fund that invests in several different small capitalization equity styles in order to reduce the risk of price and return volatility associated with reliance on a a single equity style. It invests in securities of companies with market capitalizations equal to or lower than the company with the largest market capitalization in the Russell 2000 Index.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Diversified Sm Adm

Fund.ManagerBio: Newell is president and a portfolio manager with Newell Associates. She joined the firm in 1992 and its investment team in 1993 and was appointed president in 1997. Previously, she served as assistant vice president and manager of product support with Putnam Investments, her employer from 1987 to 1992. Prior to that, she was a marketing assistant with Massachusetts Financial Services from 1986 to 1987. Newell holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks above-average dividend income and long-term capital appreciation. The fund invests principally in dividend-paying securities. Specifically, the fund seeks to invest primarily in securities with dividend yields that are at least 25% higher than the yield of the S&P Industrials Index. The fund may invest up to 25% of the fund's assets in foreign securities through ADRs and similar investments.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Dividend Income Ad

Fund.ManagerBio: Alldredge co-founded GIA in 1994 and currently serves as co-portfolio manager and senior analyst of GIA, which provides advisory services, a series of collective investment funds. He has served as a consulting analyst and asset allocation strategist for both defined benefit and defined contribution retirement plans since 1989.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return for investors retiring or begin to withdraw substantial portions of their investment in approximately the year 2010. The fund uses an asset allocation strategy designed to replicate the total return of the Dow Jones Target 2010 index. It attempts to achieve at least a 95% correlation between the performance of the index and the funds investment results. The Dow Jones Target 2010 index's hypothetical portfolio resulted in allocations of approximately: 26% equity securities, 44% fixed income securities and 30% money market instruments.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage DJ Target 2010 A

Fund.FundSummary: Wells Fargo Advantage Outlook 2020 Fund seeks total return for investors retiring in approximately the year 2020. The fund uses an asset-allocation approach; a neutral mix would be 65% equities and 35% debt securities. The fund allocates assets among securities contained in various domestic and foreign indexes; it may invest up to 20% of assets in foreign securities. The asset mix grows more conservative as the fund nears its maturity date.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage DJ Target 2020 A

Fund.ManagerBio: Alldredge co-founded GIA in 1994 and currently serves as co-portfolio manager and senior analyst of GIA, which provides advisory services, a series of collective investment funds. He has served as a consulting analyst and asset allocation strategist for both defined benefit and defined contribution retirement plans since 1989.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return for investors retiring or begin to withdraw substantial portions of their investment in approximately the year 2020. The fund uses an asset allocation strategy designed to replicate the total return of the Dow Jones Target 2020 index. It attempts to achieve at least a 95% correlation between the performance of the index and the funds investment results. The Dow Jones Target 2020 index's hypothetical portfolio resulted in allocations of approximately: 53% equity securities, 43% fixed income securities and 4% money market instruments.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage DJ Target 2020 Adm

Fund.ManagerBio: Jimenez serves as a senior portfolio manager with Wells Capital Management. Prior to joining Wells, she was a senior portfolio manager responsible for emerging markets investments at Montgomery Asset Management. Prior to that, she worked as portfolio manager at Emerging Markets Investors Corporation. From 1981 through 1988, she worked as analyst of U.S. equities, first at MassMutual then at Shawmut Corp. Jimenez has earned the right to use the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. The fund normally invests at least 65% of assets in equities from three to 10 emerging market countries. It may invest up to 50% of assets in a single country. The fund may concentrate investments in one or more market sectors. It may invest up to 35% of assets in debt securities.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Emerg Mkt Focus A

Fund.ManagerBio: Cragg worked in Wells Capital Mnagement from 2005. Prior he joined Strong Capital Management as a portfolio manager in 1993. Previously, Cragg spent seven years as an executive managing director and portfolio manager with Dillon Read International Asset Management. From 1980 to 1986, Cragg worked at Gartmore, first as a director in the companys Hong Kong office, and then as a managing director in its Japan office.

Fund.ManagerBio: Pence is a portfolio manager at Wells Fargo. Previously, he was a portfolio manager with Strong Capital Management from October 2000 to April 2005. Previously, he was chief equity investment officer and portfolio manager at Conseco Capital Management and a senior security analyst at another company in the forest-products and natural-gas industries. Pence holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in securities of large-capitalization companies as those with market capitalization of $3 billion or more, and up to 25% of assets in foreign securities through ADRs and similar investments. The fund seeks to identify companies that have the prospect for improving sales and earning growth rates, enjoy a competitive advantage and have effective management with a history of making investments that are in the best interests of shareholders. It may invest in any sector.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Endeavor Lrg Cap A

Fund.ManagerBio: Pence is a portfolio manager at Wells Fargo. Previously, he was a portfolio manager with Strong Capital Management from October 2000 to April 2005. Fund.ManagerBio: Pence is a portfolio manager at Wells Fargo. Previously, he was a portfolio manager with Strong Capital Management from October 2000 to April 2005. Previously, he was chief equity investment officer and portfolio manager at Conseco Capital Management and a senior security analyst at another company in the forest-products and natural-gas industries. Pence holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation.The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in equity securities and up to 25% of assets in foreign securities through ADRs and similar investments. It principally invests in the equity securities of 30 to 40 companies that its managers believe that have above-average earnings growth prospects. The fund selects equity securities of any size that have attractive prospects, accelerating sales and earnings and positive fundamentals. It may invest in any sector, and at times the fund may emphasize one or more particular sectors. It is non-diversified.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Endeavor Select A

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital growth. The fund normally invests in stocks of small and medium-capitalization companies, though it may invest in companies of any size. The fund's manager strives to find leading companies in rapidly growing industries such as business services, computer and digital products, financial services, healthcare services, internet-related companies, medical technology, retail, and telecommunications. The fund may also invest up to 25% of assets in foreign securities.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Enterprise Adm

Holding.Company: DU PONT E I DE NEM

Fund.ManagerBio: Dunn joined Wells Capital Management in 1998 as principal of its equity income team. He formerly was the director of institutional investments with Norwest Investment Mangement until it combined investment advisory services under the WCM name in 1999. Dunn has been associated with Norwest or its affiliates as a financial analyst and portfolio manager since 1979. Dunn holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation and dividend income. The fund normally invests at least 65% of assets in equities issued by companies with capitalizations of at least $600 million that are judged to have above-average return potential, based on current market valuations. The advisor seeks stocks with above-average dividend yields and below-average P\E, P\B, and price\sales ratios. It may also invest in depositary receipts.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Equity Income A

Fund.ManagerBio: Genung joined Wells Fargo in 2001. Previously, he was a securities trader at Norwest Investment Services, Inc. since 1994. Earlier, he worked with Piper Capital Management, where he became senior advisory account administrator, specializing in mortgage-backed derivative products. Genung holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to approximate, to the extent practicable, the total rate of return of the stocks composing the S&P 500 index. The fund invests assets in substantially the same stocks, and in substantially the same percentages, as the S&P 500 index. It expects to achieve at least a 0.95 correlation with the total return performance of the index.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Equity Index A

Fund.ManagerBio: Genung joined Wells Fargo in 2001. Previously, he was a securities trader at Norwest Investment Services, Inc. since 1994. Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to duplicate the return of the S&P 500 Index. The fund invests in common stocks to replicate the total rate of return of the S&P 500 index, before fees and expenses. It invests in each company comprising the S&P 500 index in proportion to its weighting in the index. The fund attempts to achieve at least a 95% correlation between the performance of the index and the funds investment results, before fees and expenses.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Index Adm

Fund.ManagerBio: Mueller joined Wells Capital Management in 2005 as a portfolio manager. Prior to joining Wells Capital Management, he was a portfolio manager with SCM since 1991. He also served as Director of Fixed Income for SCM from July 2002 to July 2004. Prior to joining SCM, he was a securities analyst and portfolio manager at R. Meeder & Associates. He began his investment career at Harris Trust & Savings Bank as an investment analyst.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return while providing protection against inflation. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in inflation-protected debt securities. It may also invest up to 20% of assets in adjustable or variable rate securities, including mortgage-backed and other asset-backed securities. The fund purchases only securities that are rated, at the time of purchase, within the two highest rating categories assigned by a Nationally Recognized Statistical Ratings Organization, or, if unrated, are determined to be of comparable quality.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Infl Prot Bond A

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation. The fund normally invests at least 85% of assets in equities issued in at least six emerging-market countries. It uses a proprietary, quantitative asset allocation model to help determine the percentage of assets to invest in each country. The advisor selects individual stocks based on fundamental analysis. It may invest up to 15% of assets in debt securities, up to 5% of which may be rated below investment-grade.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Inst Emerg Mkt

Fund.ManagerBio: William Stevens, is President and CIO of Montgomery Asset Management with oversight responsibilities for all investment-related activities and is co-head of the Fixed Income Division. Prior to joining Montgomery, he was responsible for starting the collateralized mortgage obligation and asset-backed securities trading department at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities. Prior to that he headed the Structured Product Department at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide current income consistent with safety of principal. The fund normally invests at least 80% of the funds assets in U.S. government obligations, including repurchase agreements collateralized by U.S. government obligations, up to 20% of the funds assets in non-government mortgage- and asset-backed securities, and up to 10% of total assets in stripped treasury and stripped mortgage-backed securities, including zero coupon securities. The dollar-weighted average effective maturity of the fund generally ranges from 3 to 10 years.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Interm Govt Inc A

Fund.ManagerBio: William Stevens, is President and CIO of Montgomery Asset Management with oversight responsibilities for all investment-related activities and is co-head of the Fixed Income Division. Prior to that he headed the Structured Product Department at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide current income consistent with safety of principal. The fund normally invests at least 80% of the funds assets in U.S. government obligations, including repurchase agreements collateralized by U.S. government obligations, up to 20% of the funds assets in non-government mortgage- and asset-backed securities, and up to 10% of total assets in stripped treasury and stripped mortgage-backed securities, including zero coupon securities. The dollar-weighted average effective maturity of the fund generally ranges from 3 to 10 years.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Interm Govt Inc B

Fund.ManagerBio: William Stevens, is President and CIO of Montgomery Asset Management with oversight responsibilities for all investment-related activities and is co-head of the Fixed Income Division. Fund.ManagerBio: Fitterer is a portfolio manager with Wells Fargo. Prior to that, Fitterer was with Strong Capital Management from 1989 to April 2005. Previously, he served as a fixed-income research analyst and trader and as a manager of the Strong Funds fixed-income accounting department. Fitterer is a Chartered Financial Analyst and a Certified Public Accountant.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return that is federally tax-exempt. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in municipal bonds, including intermediate-term, higher and medium-quality muncipal bonds. It may also invest up to 15% of its assets in securities that are of lower quality. The fund may also invest up 20% of it's net assets in taxable securities of comparable quality to it's investment in municipal obligations; including U.S. Government securities, bank,corporate obligations, and short term fixed income securities. The fund usually maintains an average effective maturity between three and ten years.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Interm T/F Bd Inv

Fund.ManagerBio: Bannick is a managing director and portfolio manager with Cadence Capital Management. Prior to joining the company in October 1992, he spent two years as executive vice president and portfolio manager with George D. Bjorman & Associates. Before that, he managed portfolios for Trinity Investment Management from 1984 to 1990. Bannick holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. Under normal conditions, the fund invests at least 80% of assets in the stocks of US companies whose shares have a market capitalization within the range of the Russell 1000 index at the time of purchase. The fund advisor screens the 1,000 largest publicly traded companies in the US for a series of growth and value criteria.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Large Cap Appr A

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks capital appreciation.The fund invests principally in securities of large-capitalization companies, which are defined as those with market capitalizations of $3 billion or more. The fund may invest up to 25% of the fund's assets in foreign securities through ADRs and similar investments.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Large Cap Gr Inv

Fund.ManagerBio: Katz is the president and chief investment officer of Matrix Asset Advisors, where he is currently employed. Katz co-founded Value Matrix Management in 1986. In 1990, he merged Value Matrix Management into Matrix Asset Advisors. Prior to forming Matrix, he served on the investment policy committee at Management Asset Corporation in 1984. Katz holds the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return comprised of long-term capital appreciation and current income. The fund invests at least 80% of assets in securities of large-capitalization companies, as those with market capitalization of $3 billion or more, and up to 25% of assets in foreign securities through ADRs and similar investments. The fund selects companies that its managers believe are financially strong and meet specific valuation criteria as compared to the overall market and the companies own valuation histories. The Fund tends to invest in large, established companies, the majority of which pay dividends.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Large Co Core A

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks current income exempt from federal and Minnesota income taxes. The fund normally invests at least 80% of assets in municipal securities that pay interest exempt from federal income tax and Minnesota individual income tax; up to 25% of total assets in securities of related issuers or in securities of any one issuer; up to 20% of the funds assets in securities that pay interest subject to federal income taxes, including federal AMT; and up to 10% of total assets in below investment-grade municipal securities, including unrated securities which are classified as below investment-grade quality. The fund is nondiversified.

The fund invests primarily investment-grade issues, of which 45% are intermediate-term fixed-income securities and 15% are short-term debt.

Fund.ManagerBio: William Stevens, is President and CIO of Montgomery Asset Management with oversight responsibilities for all investment-related activities and is co-head of the Fixed Income Division. Prior to joining Montgomery, he was responsible for starting the collateralized mortgage obligation and asset-backed securities trading department at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities. Prior to that he headed the Structured Product Department at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks to provide current income consistent with capital preservation. The fund normally invests at least 80% of the funds assets in U.S. Government obligations, up to 20% of the funds assets in non-government mortgage- and asset-backed securities, and up to 10% of total assets in stripped treasury and stripped mortgage-backed securities, including zero coupon securities. The fund purchases only securities that are rated, at the time of purchase, within the two highest rating categories assigned by a Nationally Recognized Statistical Ratings Organization, or, if unrated, are determined to be of comparable quality.

Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks long-term capital appreciation. Fund.ManagerBio: Merriam was named portfolio manager on the Wells Fargo Stable Income Fund in 2004. He has been a managing partner and portfolio manager with Galliard Capital Management since the firms inception in 1995. Previously, he was chief investment officer of Insight Investment Management. Prior to that, he served as a senior vice president at Washington Square Capital. He has over 13 years of investment management experience. Merriam has earned his right to use the Chartered Financial Analyst designation.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks stability of principal while providing lower volatility total return. The fund normally invests at least 80% of the funds assets in income-producing debt securities, up to 65% of total assets in mortgage-backed securities, up to 35% of total assets in asset-backed securities, up to 25% of total assets in mortgage-backed securities that are not U.S. government obligations, up to 50% of total assets in U.S. Government obligations, and up to 10% of total assets in fixed or variable rate dollar-denominated debt securities of foreign issuers. It seeks to maintain a dollar-weighted average maturity between 1 and 5 years.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Stable Income A

Prior to joining Montgomery, he was responsible for starting the collateralized mortgage obligation and asset-backed securities trading department at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities. Prior to that he headed the Structured Product Department at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return consisting of income and capital appreciation. The fund normally invests at least 80% of the funds assets in bonds, at least 80% of total assets in investment-grade debt securities, up to 25% of total assets in asset-backed securities other than mortgage-backed securities, up to 20% of total assets in dollar-denominated obligations of foreign issuers, and up to 10% of total assets in stripped mortgage-backed securities. It expects to maintain an overall effective duration range between four and 5.5 years.
Fund.Name: Wells Fargo Advantage Tot Return Bond C

Fund.ManagerBio: Price joined Wells Capital Management in 2005 as a portfolio manager. Prior to joining Wells Capital Management, he was with SCM since April 1996 as a fixed income research analyst and, since May 1998, as a portfolio manager. Price began his investment career at Houlihan, Lokey, Howard & Zukin as a financial analyst and later joined Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance as a high-yield bond analyst.
Fund.FundSummary: The investment seeks total return by investing for a high level of income. The fund invests at least 80% of its net assets in bonds from U.S. issuers, and up to 20% of its net assets may be invested in lower quality, high yield bonds. Under normal conditions, the fund maintains a duration of three years or less.
